text:
You know, a lot of people do whatever
it takes to get the job done.

But should we be working harder
or should we be going
easier and enjoying our lives?

As more people return to the office, I'm
asking myself this question more and more.

So I'm going to get to the bottom of it
right here at our Oktoberfest!
I haven't drank in two years.
Let's see how this goes.
Do you think people work too hard?

Some people definitely do.
Talk to me about work.
Do you know what quiet quitting is?
No. I don't.
No.
Quiet quitting, yes.

Quiet quitting is this trend
where people think that you shouldn't
care as much about work.

You should be focused
more on your personal life.
And the hustle culture is destroying us.

I think the remote work environment
has caused a lot of video game playing,

which has been confused 
for quiet quitting.
It's a really hot topic right now.
So hot. Yeah.

I mean, I feel like people only quiet quit
if their boss or their employer

sucks so bad that they're like
zapped of motivation at all.
Probably not the best way to get ahead.
But if you're in a job where you know

you're just waiting for the opportunity
to go do something else,

then you don't care about getting ahead
in that field anyway.

You've got to do it. You got to do it.
What do you think of quiet quitting?
I don't know.

I think it's just another buzzword
for people to write articles about.
I think it'll die out in a month or two.
I think it's a bad thing.

The work product is pretty poor,
but I think it's not what we think it is.

I don't think people are withdrawn
from their work per se.

I just think remote work is not conducive
to good quality output.

No, I think it's just
people like asserting their boundaries,
which is a good thing.

And I think if you work at a company
that has a really good work life balance,

then there's space for you to say like,
you know what, I'm approaching burnout
and I need to take a step back.

Especially young men
spend a lot of time at home,

and when they're unsupervised,
it's never good.

They rip into the video— 
It’s never good.
And other things.
Oh, no.

They rip into things.
What are you talking about?

How do you, like, manage
work life balance?
We work for a Scandinavian company,

so they are really focused on work life
balance and the concept of hygee and—
Concept of what?
What's hygee?
It's like a Danish word that means

cozy, like sitting in front of a fireplace
with a blanket over you is hygee.
I want some hygee.
We have a head of hygee.

Do Americans focus too much 
on the hustle and not as much as
on work life balance?
I'd say it depends.

In Europe, on the continent,
there's a better work life balance.
It’s different culture.

You don't have the American,
I'm going to grind. I'm going to grind.

I'm going to work a lot.
I'm going to work more than I need to.
You ever heard of YOLO?
Cheers. Cheers.

Cheers, everyone.
That looks amazing.
Oh.

What do you think about, like,
hustle culture, though?
Don't you think that we should be working

harder, hustling,
like busting our butt grinding?
I do like the hustle.

I like to succeed in my career, but
I also have a lot of personal endeavors

that I really enjoy
and like spending time with.

And I think that's really important for
people to take the time for that to do.

I think hustling is good, but
I think we have a younger class of people

that feel very entitled to things
rather than working hard for things.
Interesting.

They expect promotion,
they expect big bonuses,

but they don't necessarily work
for those things.

Depends like you don't really get paid
to do extra other things.

So I get paid to be there.
Do your job and then go home.
Cheers. Cheers.
Yes, yes.
Today was amazing.

We learned that everybody appreciates
work life balance and employers shouldn't
expect too much from us

because we're all just trying
to live our best life here at Oktoberfest

For morning Brew, I'm Willy Appleman,
